text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with norwegian potato flatbread

that's right you're about to learn how
to make left side from a person who's

only made it a few times which is both
the bad and the good news all right the

bad news is I'm not gonna be able to
give you lots of expert tips and tricks

due to lack of experience but the good
news is without really knowing what I

was doing these came out really well
and they are now one of my favorite new

things to eat so with that let's go
ahead and get started and the first

thing I'm gonna do is roast a potato and
before we do that we'll give it the old

polka polka with a knife which will
allow some of the steam from inside to

escape which by the way is why I'm
putting this on foil and not wrapping

the potato in foil and then once our
potato has been panned and poked we will

roast that in a 400 degree oven for
about an hour or so or until very very

tender and of course we will need to
test that with a knife which should

slide in easily with no effort and then
what we'll do once our potatoes baked is

simply let it sit there until it's cool
enough to handle and speaking of cool

handles we always 100 percent of the
time leave the towel on a handle of a

pan that just came out of the oven
otherwise some innocent bystander might

grab and burn themselves and then what
we'll do once that's cooled down enough

to handle but still very warm is go
ahead and split it open at which point

we will scoop everything except the skin
into a bowl and by the way one of the

keys here is try to do this while it's
still very warm okay it's just gonna be

a lot easier to scoop and mash which by
the way is the next step okay so once

that scooped we'll go ahead and mash it
very smooth which as you can see I like

to do with the back of a spatula
having said that by the way if you're

real lefse maker you'd use a ricer
which is like a press that squeezes the

potato between little holes but you
probably don't have one and I don't

really feel like washing one so for me
the spatula works just fine and besides

a couple tiny little arms aren't a
problem that's how people will know

these are homemade lefse and not those
store-bought ones but anyway no matter

what you use we will mash that smooth at
which point we will add a few chunks of

butter and we'll continue mixing and
mashing smear and Anna smashing until

that butter disappears which is another
reason we want to make sure these

they're still warm and then what we'll
do once that's incorporated is stop and

add some salt as well as a little bit of
sugar and then a nice big splash of

heavy cream although if you want I'm
told by my sources in North Dakota that

just regular milk will work and that's
it well go ahead and take our spatula

mix all this together until the mixture
is completely smooth and once that's

been accomplished what we'll do is cover
this in plastic and we'll pop it in the

fridge until completely chilled which
apparently is an important step before

we add our flour even though some of the
recipes I saw just add the flour

straight away but anyway if you're
keeping score at home I did chill mine

for a couple hours at which point we can
pull it out and add the last ingredient

some all-purpose flour and just like
almost every dough recipe we do we don't

want to add all the flour at once so I
went ahead and dumped in about 2/3 of it

and then gave it a mix and once that's
incorporated we can give that a little

test by pressing with our fingers to see
how white the mixture still is and if

it's still fairly wet and sticky we will
add more which mine was and basically

we're gonna keep doing that until the
texture of our dough is exactly how we

want it and by the way once you've added
enough flour and it's not too sticky

we can switch to our hands and of course
the more flour you add the easier this

is going to be to roll and work with but
if we add too much it might end up being

tough and dry and not retain that nice
potatoey flavor and of course I'm gonna

give you the measurements I used but
there is very little chance that's

exactly how much you're gonna use so
please be prepared to feel and adjust

I mean you are after all the þór of
whether to add more and you'll know if

you have to because you're gonna be the
one feeling it but anyway to summarize I

added that flour in a few additions
until it was feeling just right and I'd

produced a nice and soft but not too
sticky dough and then once we feel like

our dough is perfect what we'll do is
transfer that I'm some plastic and form

it into a log and then transfer that
into the fridge until thoroughly chilled

and why did I make a log instead of just
leaving it in the bowl I have no idea

all right sometimes my arms and hands
just do things on their own but anyway

the point is we will wrap that up and
pop it in the fridge until chilled what

fine we can pull it out unwrap it and
start rolling which I'm going to do on a

very very well floured kitchen towel and
I do try this originally on the table

and on a cutting board but for me this
flowered towel will work the best but

anyway what we'll do is go ahead and
pull off a nice ball of dough and we'll

go ahead and eat in a little bit of
flour and sort of form it into a disc at

which point we will attempt to roll this
out nice and thin and I should mention

the authentic lefse are much bigger and
that people making them you're using

these special rollers that have grooves
in them and they're covered with a

special fabric and it's a whole
production but as you're about to see

this is possible just using a standard
kitchen equipment and by not trying to

make these super big they're gonna be a
lot easier to handle so we'll go ahead

and roll that out as thin as we can but
we're still thick enough where we can

remove it and get it into the pan and
for the dismount I like to grab one side

and kind of flip it over my other hand
and then using both hands we will

carefully transfer that onto a nonstick
pan which we have set over medium-high

heat and by the way that pan was mostly
dry but while it was heating up I did

rub it a little bit with a very very
lightly buttered paper towel and then

what I did as soon as that was placed in
this gave that surface a little poking

with a fork which is going to prevent
any big bubbles from forming okay we're

not trying to make pita bread here and
we don't want this to balloon up so I

went ahead and poked mine here and there
and what we'll do is give that first

side about two or three minutes or until
we have some nice golden brown blisters

forming and then once that's been
flipped over we'll give the other side

two or three minutes and it's been my
experience that the blisters on the

second side are going to get a little
darker which i think looks amazing and

possibly authentic and that's it we'll
go ahead and transfer that onto a plate

and we will continue on until all our
dough is cooked although I did stop

production to eat this one and
traditionally these are enjoyed very

simply by being spread with butter and
sprinkled with sugar oh and pro tip do

not use ice-cold butter out of the
fridge all right let it get soft and

spreadable but anyway eventually my
warmed up and I spread it over and like

I said these are traditionally sprinkled
with sugar but I didn't do that as I was

in more of a savory mood and we will
go ahead and roll that up and what we

have here is something that's very
tender very supple almost fabric like in

texture with a very delicious taste
somewhere between a crepe and a potato

pancake just very delicious and
addictive and again for not having any

of the equipment or really knowing what
I was doing these came out surprisingly

well so I finished this one and rolled
and cooked the rest

and like any time I'm making flat bread
or tortilla or crepes I generally like

to pile them up and cover it with a
towel to keep them warm alright I think

that's going to keep them from drying
out and also of course will trap in that

residual heat and that's it once we're
done we can enjoy these immediately or

I've heard from my Norwegian friends
Norwegian nor we my friends from Norway

we can actually freeze these and reheat
them when we want so something to keep

in mind and then as far as service goes
there are two classic ways to present

these we can roll them in stack them
which does look pretty cool and is

totally tubular or the other classic
presentation would be to simply fold

these into triangles also very
attractive and then as far as serving

suggestions go
like I said butter and sprinkles sugar

is the most common but besides that one
of my favorite ways to enjoy these would

be with some sliced smoked salmon topped
with a spoon or two of sour cream and

possibly some freshly picked dill and
that is just a simple but magnificent

snack right that would make a perfect
fancy brunch or breakfast item oh and

here I'm rolling and simultaneously
trying to pick up a speck of dill which

did not work at all and yes you do get
extra credit if you use caviar instead

of the salmon or in addition to I guess
so that I think would be my second

forever way to use these my favorite I
think is just simply brush with butter

and then spread was some kind of berry
jam which in the land of the lefse I

think would be lingonberry but my
neighborhood market didn't carry that so

I believe this was Marion Barry but
anything would work and then to that I

like to schmear in a little bit of sour
cream and then because we rolled the

last one we'll go ahead and fold this
one into a triangle in that with a cup

of tea or coffee it's just
about the best way you could start a day

but anyway that's it my take on
Norwegian potato flatbread all right

these are a little too thick to call
crepes and not quite thick enough to

call pancakes so we're going with
flatbread although what we really should

be calling them is lefse but anyway no
matter what you call them or how you

describe it I really do hope you give
them a try soon so please follow the

links below for all the ingredient
amounts a principle written recipe in
much more info as usual and as always
you
